_prev_prog_3.Description: QCNPS's process is actually a combination of interconnected plant systems that use hydrogen.  The combined quantity of hydrogen used in these systems exceeds the threshold quantity for hydrogen.  The systems interconnected are: the Hydrogen Water Chemistry System (provides hydrogen to reduce corrosion potential of reactor internal components), the Generator Cooling System (provides cooling media for keeping the generators cool, when running), the Hydrogen Control System (maintains sufficient amounts of hydrogen in the generator), and the Hydrogen Seal Oil System (provides seal mechanism keeping hydrogen in the generator, when operational).  These are two identical systems, of each type, one for Unit 1 and one for Unit 2.  All hydrogen for these systems originates from the Hydrogen Storage Facility.  All portions of this standard apply to various systems noted above.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary: 40 CFR 68.155

Quad Cities Nuclear Power Station (QCNPS) is a dual unit boiling water reactor (BWR).  QCNPS has two 2511 mega-watt thermal rated reactors generating electricity for northern Illinois.  QCNPS is located in the northwest corner of Illinois' Rock Island County.  The Mississippi River forms the western border of the 784 acre site.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at QCNPS:

It is the policy of QCNPS to perform work activities in a professional, skilled, and highly competent  manner.  Safety is our number one priority, in both spirit and action.  Our policies drive our employees toward the performance of activities in an atmosphere where conservative decision making and safe work practices are our norm.  Our Safety Handbook, procedures, and policies all are driven by this desire to perform activities in a safe manner.  Our Team at QCNPS, both Management and Bargaining Union employees (Local 15 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers), are committed to providing and maintaining a safe environment.  We are, however, prepared to deal with any anticipated emergency situation.  Highly dedicated individuals compliment our emergency response policies by providing a highly trained, highly competent, and highly skilled response efforts.  We have policies and measures in-place compliant with the following emergency response requirements:  Fire, Medical, Hazardous Materials Emergency Response (HAZMAT), Resource Conservation & Recovery Act (RCRA), Spill Prevention Control & Countermeasure Plan (SPCC), and General Site Emergency Plan (GSEP).     

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled at QCNPS:

Hydrogen is the only regulated substance applicable to 40 CFR 68, above the threshold quantity, used at QCNPS.  QCNPS has various interconnected plant systems that use hydrogen; the Hydrogen Water Chemistry (HWC), Generator Cooling, Hydrogen Control and Hydrogen Seal Oil systems.  Two identical system

s exist for each type of listed system, one to support each of the operating units.  The hydrogen that supplies these plant systems comes from the Hydrogen Storage Facility.  For the purposes of this standard, the hydrogen contained in these various plant systems is considered one process.  The chemistry for the combined process is simple:  Hydrogen used in HWC system has the following process chemistry: 2H2 + O2 = 2H2O.  Hydrogen injected into the feed water combines with free oxygen in the water to form water.  This "removal" of oxygen reduces the corrosion potential for reactor vessel internals.  Hydrogen is used in the Generator Cooling system as a cooling media, because of it's unique chemical properties, for the units operating generators.  Hydrogen Control makes up for lost hydrogen in the Generator Cooling system and Hydrogen Seal Oil system keeps the hydrogen in the operating generator.  For these three systems, there is no process chemistry.  The maximum intended inventory of hydrogen, in all systems making up the process, is approximately 12,000 pounds. 


QCNPS Worst-Case and Alternate Release Scenarios:

QCNPS modeled Worst-Case and Alternate Release Scenarios, based on seriousness and probability of release.  Our Worst-Case and one Alternate Release Scenario result in an endpoint that leaves our facilities' site boundaries, as modeled by the EPA's RMP*Comp program.  Fortunately, QCNPS has no projected impact to population receptors (other than people who would happen to be on the Mississippi River, should a worst-case type event occur) and only slight impact to environmental receptors, the Mississippi River.  The modeling methods for this type of release are extremely conservative when compared to most applicable models available.  This provides some assurance that a worst-case type event would in fact have little or no impact outside the boundaries of our facility.  We still control all of our processes, maintenance activities, inspections, testing, a

nd system manipulations through a highly controlled series of checks and balances to administratively control risk at the site.  The Nuclear Power industry, due to the inherent risk a catastrophic event could pose to the public and the environment, place great importance on the procedures and policies governing our actions.  We fully comprehend the inherent dangers any catastrophic event has on the site, public, and the environment.  As a result, we place a significant amount of resources in planning and performing activities in a manner that minimizes a potential event.  To Limit the potential of a large release associated with the HWC system, there is a hydrogen monitoring system that monitors for hydrogen leaks around the injection piping and equipment of the HWC system.  The hydrogen line that supplies hydrogen to equipment in the protected area contains two excess (limiting) flow check valves, one at the Hydrogen Storage Facility and one in the piping where it enters the Turbine Building.  These valves are designed to isolate the line if a flow exceeds the set point, thus limiting the amount of hydrogen that could be lost.  The storage vessels and piping in the Hydrogen Storage Facility are protected from overpressure concerns by relief and safety valves.  

General Accidental Release Prevention Program for QCNPS:

QCNPS fully implemented the requirements of this standard to prevent an accidental release of hydrogen from occurring at our facility.  We have gathered safety information on the process applicable to this standard.  We have performed an extensive process hazard analysis and are currently evaluating and resolving the recommendations identified during that analysis.  Our Operations personnel are highly trained and skilled in the operation of our facility.  They have accurate complete procedures to guide them on the operations of process equipment.  These procedures are updated and revised whenever a deficiency is determined to exist.  QCNPS has an ext

ensive process in place to ensure the mechanical integrity of the process equipment is intact.  Extensive inspections, testing, and maintenance activities are performed to ensure a high state of reliability is maintained with regards to process equipment.  Vendor and QCNPS maintenance personnel are highly trained and qualified to maintain process equipment at a high state of performance.  QCNPS has a change process in place to ensure process equipment is up-graded or modified in a safe, reliable, and systematic manner.  QCNPS has processes in place to ensure proper pre-startup reviews, compliance audits, and incident investigations are and can be performed, if and when required.  We seek participation from our employees and plans are in place to utilize their expertise.  Our Hot Work Permit is in compliance with requirements of 29 CFR 1910.252(a) and is strictly enforced and used at our facility.  Our contractors also must meet or exceed the same standards we apply to our in-house work force.  We ensure they are properly trained and informed on what they need to do, how they need to do it, and most importantly, that our safety expectations are enforced. 


Five Year Accident History of QCNPS Process:

QCNPS has had no accidents involving our process in the last five years.  We did examine an event at another nuclear power plant with a similar process to ours for lessons learned and improvement items for our plan.

Emergency Response Program at QCNPS:

QCNPS has a station fire brigade, Hazardous Materials Emergency Response Team (HAZMAT Team), and emergency medical response personnel available at the site 24 hours a day, seven days a week.  A site confined space rescue team is in place any time a confined space entry warrants such coverage.  Our emergency response personnel are highly trained and competent in the response actions they are expected to perform.  As a nuclear power plant, we also have in place a highly refined General Site Emergency Plan (GSEP) that can

be activated for any site emergency that poses a threat to site personnel, the public, or the environment.  Our emergency response actions are coordinated with the Rock Island County Emergency Disaster Agency and the area medical, fire, and police organizations.  We perform quarterly fire and confined space rescue drills, annual HAZMAT and medical drills, and a yearly GSEP drill.  We participate and hold joint training and drills with local emergency response agencies.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

QCNPS will evaluate the recommendations presented by the Process Hazard Assessment Team that were identified during the initial process hazard analysis.  All actions related to the processing of these recommendations will be documented and all actions determined to be implemented will be tracked.  Implementation of any corrective action will be timely.  Additionally, any findings and or recommendations coming from the sites initial Compliance Audit (scheduled to be performed during the week of June 14th, 1999) will be processed in the same manner.  QCNPS is dedicated to providing a safe work environment for it's employees, as well as, maintaining public and environmental safety.
